content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting ! We’re starting part III of our series of meetings on the 1.52 fingerprint bug, aka compiler-team#435
as in part 2, here is the doc: https://hackmd.io/DhKzaRUgTVGSmhW8Mj0c8A?view
my memory is that we got to spend a while last time discussing the “Five Whys” themselves, but I cannot remember how far we got into Lessons Learned etc

anyway, the document opens with a checklist of things to cover. I propose we take maybe five minutes now to just review the doc (presumably starting from Lessons Learned), and then we can start on the checklist beyond that.
I believe we had gotten to the why of "Why did it take until Monday for you to tell your users about the problem?"
ah thanks @Wesley Wiser
based on the conversation at the end of the meeting
did we jump ahead to that one? Because its at the end of the tree of Five Whys

(I interpret "Why don’t you have a lighter weight means than big blog posts to communicate important changes in status to your users, such as a banner on the website or a social media account?” as being attached to it, as a branch of the tree.)
I'm not sure we were discussing the why's in order.
ah okay
(I should have reviewed last week’s meeting before starting this one. Its been a packed morning.)
Anyway, lets do this: lets take 2 more minutes to read Lessons Learned and beyond. People can also skim the Five Whys and bring up ones that they want to discuss, before we jump into the check list.
Okay, that’s two minutes. Does anyone need more time?
(I interpret :check: as “lets move forward!”)
First question
does anyone want to dig into any of the Five Whys more?
(I’m not speaking of fine-tuning the phrasing of the text right now, but rather big picture issues.)
one possible outcome from last time was that we might want to issue PSAs via rustup or something similar
did we note that somewhere?
That’s right, that was an corrective action that was discussed at the meeting last time
Let me add a section to the top of the doc
with “new proposed actions"
(5a) kind of covers it but could be more specific

Why are you not putting proper diagnostics on the ICE’s that have been long-lived, since the Rust project cannot provide a guarantee that all ICE’s will be short-lived?

I'm not sure I understand what is meant by "proper diagnostics" or what value that brings to users or rustc devs.

(I'm only bringing this up because it's also called out in the Corrective Actions section)
ah yes, clarifying questions is good
“Proper diagnostics” means our usual diagnostic system
improper diagnostics are results from panic! or assert!, etc
There are two types of ICEs: some are invalid code that can be fixed "just" by creating a proper error.
Invalid input code, right?
or rather, panics that are caused by invalid input Rust source
and thus, the fix is a proper error
The second is code that should have been accepted, I'd have some pushback against making these have proper diagnostics
Yes, felix
Ok, that's what I thought. I guess I'm just missing 1) how would we attach some arbitrary panic! to a location in user source code and 2) does that send the wrong message to users?

Esteban Küber said:

The second is code that should have been accepted, I'd have some pushback against making these have proper diagnostics

Okay, I welcome pushback here
For the second case,it feels like we're giving up...
Instead of fixing the actual problem
For invalid input I'm mote than ok with silencing those with delay_span_bug
Yeah, that's kind of what I meant by "sends the wrong message". To me, it tells users they should change their code instead of "this is a rustc bug"
Indeed. And a long-lived ICE that users are not commonly hitting does not sound worth putting a so-called “proper diagnostic” one.
My concern are about cases where we know that people hit the bug
and we should be doing a better job of giving them guidance in the short term
while not diluting the core message that this is a rustc bug
I totally agree that I don’t want to shift the messaging there
were there workaround suggestions in the updated ICE message? or just pointers about reporting the bug?

e.g. we should continue to instruct people to file a bug. (Or, for long-lived ICEs, maybe we include a pre-existing bug number, and ask them to … hmmm. Add yet another comment to the pre-existing issue?)
@Taylor Yu [they/she] are you asking about the specific case of the fingerprint issue?

pnkfelix said:

Taylor Yu [they/she] are you asking about the specific case of the fingerprint issue?

yeah
My understanding is that we deliberately added work-around suggestions
so that people could recover
@Esteban Küber honestly, I’d be willing to remove the parts about putting “proper” diagnostics on long-lived ICEs
that’s a part of the doc that was written relatively early on, when I didn’t have much notion of what we should do
since then, the continued work here has brought up other corrective actions
The idea of being able to set links to existing tickets has legs
and so I think its reasonable to remove that branch of thinking from the Five Why’s section. I think Niko had said at the outset that they thought it was a distraction from the real problem.

ok i just reread the copy of the fingerprint ICE message that i saved in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/86013 and i think there are ways we could improve it (and other messages like it in the future)
So id like that idea not to be lost, but agree with the general thinking

Esteban Küber said:

The idea of being able to set links to existing tickets has legs

Yeah, it seems like helping draw those cases together would potentially help a lot
I’ll add an item to the top of the doc
I’ll independently figure out whether to keep the text, or how to revise it smoothly
Anything else about the Five Why’s that anyone wants to discuss?
I figure otherwise, lets move into talking about the Lessons Learned
see if there’s pushback there

(The bullet list at the top of the doc from last week did say “get feedback on … what to elaborate on, and what to cut.” — so I am welcoming editorial suggestions, at least for this section and the ones following it.)
I’ll just state each Lesson Learned and see how the crowd reacts. :)

1. We need better visibility (or more advertisement within the teams) of when user-disruptive changes are scheduled to hit.
    * Notably, PR #83007 was known to inject ICE's, and it had been assigned a github milestone of 1.52.0. However, we didn't see that PR, or its milestone, when we were planning our next steps as part of reviewing issue #84970
any disagreement on this point?
sgtm
1. We need better tracking of when certain ICE's start becoming more serious problems for our users.
(that alone actually sounds like a motivation for providing the pre-made issue links that @Esteban Küber mentioned above)
sounds rather similar to (1)
oh, no, I think they’re a little different
1. is about predicting what will happen based on release train
1. is about understanding what’s happening in the wild, after the release has gone out
ok, that makes sense
"Tracking when ices become serious" is something that we can only do reliably with crash reporting/telemetry
but maybe could be clarified in the text

mw said:

but maybe could be clarified in the text

true. I can work on that. I’ll add item to top
We can infer with ticket reports, but if a ticket already exists that will discourage people from commenting
yes, I agree that Telemetry is the right long-term answer
This case was frequent enough and affected a lot of people that we heard about it, but it was still a handful of reports on the day of.
but I also think that in the short-term, prebaked issue numbers, along with a really easy way for people to register that they’ve hit it, could be good
The main tradeoff is whether to rely on existing github workflows, and thus rely on people leaving a comment or emoji, etc

or do we invent a new workflow, i.e. a URL that you follow, and it first registers in some database elsewhere that someone clicked the URL associated with that ICE, and then takes the person to github
i think for crash reporting, we can't rely on users having established a prior relationship with github (for whatever reason)
(the point being in the latter case, with “one click” from the user, we get to register the event happening)
yeah I agree with that, @Taylor Yu [they/she]
Anyway, we can fine tune the approach
(for that matter, even if they have a github account, they might not wish to associate it with the crash report)
in my mind, I definitely am on the fence, in terms of how much effort to invest in a url-based solution that fundamentally cannot provide the same quality data that telemetry would.
anyway, lets move to next Lesson

1. We need to stop unfixed ICEs from becoming problems that we never hear about.

    * (Arguably we didn't learn this lesson from this event, but rather from a particular line of Socratic inquiry.)
I’m willing to drop this Lesson
I’d be curious to hear what others think about whether we should keep it or not
(its basically an implicit argument for Telemetry, I think.)
I think the comment can be dropped in any case
@mw you mean The " (Arguably we didn't learn this lesson from this event, but rather from a particular line of Socratic inquiry.)”, right?
but it is kind of the same as (2)
Yeah, true. Okay, I’m fine with folding this into (2.)
I’ll review, try to figure out why the Five Whys process led me to make separate items for (2.) and (3.)
(2) feels to me like "users are reporting the issue on GH but we didn't notice they're all related to the same issue" and (3) feels to me like "users aren't reporting issues"
(Arguments for telemetry can be made independently of this for)
But I agree, they seem to be similar enough that they can be consolidated.
Yeah, I think we can consolidate and maybe just spell both scenarios out as part of the same lesson.

Esteban Küber said:

(Arguments for telemetry can be made independently of this for)

yes, but I’m especially interested in pointing out cases where Telemetry is the only answer
next lesson
1. We need better testing of representative user workflows (i.e., debug builds) in our pipeline; at the very least, sometime prior to a stable release.
does that mean automated testing?
any arguments here? Am I potentially overlooking existing CI builders that exist but for some reason didn’t catch this?
or getting more folks to use beta?
Ah, that’s an excellent point
In corrective actions, I linked this lesson to increased use of the betas
but I don’t know why I didn’t also bring up adding more automated testing
I think both are warranted
and implied by the lesson

i'm thinking it would need CI that simulates a development workflow, which possibly means hooking up stuff to external open source repositories and replaying diffs with incrementals turned on. sounds expensive but not impossible?
@mw the incr-comp development work did exactly that, right?
we had something like this in the past, yes
it was quite a bit of work to maintain
but it also found a lot of bugs
I do think it sounds too expensive to be part of bors’s guard on every checkin. Probably too expensive for every nightly
but it sounds entirely reasonable to make it part of the process we apply to the beta builds themselves
we ran our tool once a day
how many repositories did it use for its reference points?
or maybe “how many commits” is a better question. :)
hundreds?
best question of all: How long did it take to run?
a few hours
nothing compared to crater
sure.
but if you have to also deal with potential manual intervention
then you don’t want it to go more than a few hours
yes, having a few crates should be enough
similar to our benchmarking
Anyway, does anyone have comments on the Lesson Learned itself? The corrective actions, we can dive more deeply into those in a moment.
(I’ll add a todo item to add automated as well as manual testing associated with this lesson.)
The lesson seems good :thumbs_up:
last lesson
1. We need to be willing and able to communicate more quickly to our users in response to an event like this.
So the heart of this is the question: “Was the gap from Thursday until Monday too long"
my response is that it was, and that’s why I’ve put this lesson here
I think the team's willingness was not a problem here, right? :)
I think there has been some amount of pushback (to this being a Lesson) in the prior meeting, but I could be misremembering
Right, I think part of the problem was friction
because we, or at least I, assumed the right answer was a blog post
that needed to be curated
and in hindsight, that was just … not true. :)
We wanted to have enough information before communicating, which goes counter common incident response workflows
but what kind of information? My memory is that we were seeking to include info, at least in the blog post, about what form our response was going to take
Just sending out tweets stating "there are ices in the new stable, we're working on it" would have been better

Not to skip ahead too much, but I think having the "playbook" would be helpful here. There's a lot of questions that were unanswered on Friday so having a well thought through, curated blog post seemed like the best option.
Would stopping the distribution of the affected release have been an option?

Esteban Küber said:

Just sending out tweets stating "there are ices in the new stable, we're working on it" would have been better

Yep, I agree with this
And would have been reposted to all other likely places people would look at

The 8472 said:

Would stopping the distribution of the affected release have been an option?

Lets talk about this question
because I think its important to address it explicitly, and maybe it should have been in the document itself
I don’t think the nature of this bug warranted an outright yank of the release itself
but I want to hear arguments for why maybe it should
certainly it sounds easy to yank a release, right?
I don't think we've even done that for safety/ub issues which (at least according to the Safety First principle) would be more severe than intermittent compiler ICE.

There are two parts: our argument for not disabling the fingerprint checks is that this causes miscompilations on debug mode. Actual prod binaries were unaffected, but we still felt that the ices were worth it. Downgrading then, wasn't the answer.
Yeah. I think I would only Yank a release if it e.g. exposed user data
yeah, by that logic we rather would have had to yank all prior releases :P

I'm asking because speed (time to mitigation) seems to be a focus of the document. Which makes it sound urgent. And yanking it is the quickest action I can think of and gets results faster than... communicating.
i.e. something that actually caused harm to users
Yanking is likely quite hard, I'm not quite sure we have the tools in place to do that or would want to. static.rust-lang.org, is, well, intended to be "static" in some sense.
@The 8472 it’s true, speed is the focus of the document. But I think its important to balance that against providing the right value to our users

simulacrum said:

Yanking is likely quite hard, […]

oh, that’s interesting
and 1.52.0 was not fundamentally broken -- e.g., we need it for the bootstrap chain at least.
Letting people know that "cargo clean and carry on" was a "solution" as soon as we knew that would have been good
So, I want to just point out
that I had wanted to first double-check about whether the Lesson Learned itself
was appropriate
"cargo clean, report and carry on" right? :wink:
its great that we’re talking about the corrective actions associated with the lesson
but I first want to ensure that everyone’s in agreement that it would be better to have done something more quickly.
to me, yanking the release would have been justified for something of a severity of "miscompiles in ways that cause trivial RCE vulns in executables", and probably nothing less
(vs “Thursday to Monday delay was good enough for our project.”)
Also, we have six minutes left in meeting
I think a tweet or similar dynamic note would be appropriate
So lets take the lessons as stated, with teh edits we noted
maybe an edit to a blog post

Wesley Wiser said:

Not to skip ahead too much, but I think having the "playbook" would be helpful here. There's a lot of questions that were unanswered on Friday so having a well thought through, curated blog post seemed like the best option.

I think @Wesley Wiser has the right point here
I for one don't even know who runs @rust-lang on Twitter or what the right way to get them to Tweet something is. Do I pm Steve or something?
We should have a playbook ready for these events, and it should spell out, e.g. “put up a tweet. If its a personal tweet, then get rust-lang to retweet it.”, and then “draft a blog post”, etc.
We should not attempt to fine tune the playbook live in this meeting

pnkfelix said:

We should have a playbook ready for these events, and it should spell out, e.g. “put up a tweet. If its a personal tweet, then get rust-lang to retweet it.”, and then “draft a blog post”, etc.

we should find something that already exists (and is battle-tested) that we can adapt, if possible
Yes, sorry that was just an example of where the playbook would be helpful.

Taylor Yu [they/she] said:

pnkfelix said:

We should have a playbook ready for these events, and it should spell out, e.g. “put up a tweet. If its a personal tweet, then get rust-lang to retweet it.”, and then “draft a blog post”, etc.

we should find something that already exists (and is battle-tested) that we can adapt, if possible

Yep. I think I even put that as an action item for myself

namely this

Proposal: pnkfelix does a survey of the landscape for response playbooks during user-impacting events, especially when it comes to programming languages: what avenues/resources do we have available? What styles of communication work best when interfacing with developers?
with 3 minutes left, I’d like to focus our attention on the beta-engagement question

namely this:

Proposal: Increase usage of the beta channel, in order to provide direct testing feedback.

and this:

Proposal: Find owner to investigate ways to provide "carrots" for users to use beta, or a fork thereof ("gamma"?), rather than
stable or nightly. Perhaps try to align it with jonhoo's "Preview for Unstable Features" proposal (which has been closed, but has useful discussion).
I think there may be a parallel zulip thread about this at this point

It might be helpful to focus on languages that directly provide binaries to their users like maybe Nim/Zig/etc? My understanding is that most Python users for example probably get Python from their distro so there's a lot of distance between the project shipping a release and discovering there's a critical bug.
could we somehow "redirect" nightly to beta for the last week before the release?

Wesley Wiser said:

there's a lot of distance between the project shipping a release and discovering there's a critical bug.

This may well become more true for us as Rust becomes more successful and is “built-in” to distros

pnkfelix said:

I think there may be a parallel zulip thread about this at this point

https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/131828-t-compiler/topic/why.20is.20nightly.20so.20attractive.3F

pnkfelix said:

and this:

Proposal: Find owner to investigate ways to provide "carrots" for users to use beta, or a fork thereof ("gamma"?), rather than
stable or nightly. Perhaps try to align it with jonhoo's "Preview for Unstable Features" proposal (which has been closed, but has useful discussion).

I would really like to have a dedicated WG/team whatever of beta testers. They might also be a good candidate set of people for opt-in telemetry.
if we had telemetry on nightly wouldn't looking at the info for the last few days before promotion be enough? I find it will be hard to push many towards beta
@Wesley Wiser that is an amazingly good and simple idea

Esteban Küber said:

if we had telemetry on nightly wouldn't looking at the info for the last few days before promotion be enough? I find it will be hard to push many towards beta

beta is curated. It has the hand-picked backports
I don’t think the nightly a few days before promotion is the right comparison point in general
if nothing else, that only gives you a few days of data
It does, but this would have caught the slip of "oh don't worry, this will land on the next stable"
vs six weeks of data potentially available via beta

Esteban Küber said:

It does, but this would have caught the slip of "oh don't worry, this will land on the next stable"

hmm. I’ll have to think about that
its a good point to consider.
okay our hour is up!
I know we didn’t finish going through every detail on the doc
but I also am not sure another meeting is necessary at this point? We’re not really in a place where we are going to be assigning these action items
for now, our project structure remains “Hey, I’m throwing some ideas out there. If you feel inspired, maybe pick one of these up."
I would like to take a stab at the communication playbook idea. Do you think that would be something we should put up on the forge or maybe the rustc-dev guide?

anyway, thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! If you want to dig into any of these details further, feel free to keep talking here, or create a separate zulip thread, and we can keep talking!

Wesley Wiser said:

I would like to take a stab at the communication playbook idea. Do you think that would be something we should put up on the forge or maybe the rustc-dev guide?

That’s a good question. Probably forge I think.
But also: I really do think the right first step is to survey other projects
see what other playbooks we can steal borrow ideas from
imitation is the highest kind of flattery
i made a few comments on the doc about possibly compensating for "killing the severity signal by fixing stuff in nightly"

pnkfelix said:

I don’t think the nature of this bug warranted an outright yank of the release itself

I wasn't necessarily suggesting a permanent yank. Delaying the rollout while the situation is being assessed and resuming it later is another option.

Esteban Küber said:

if we had telemetry on nightly wouldn't looking at the info for the last few days before promotion be enough? I find it will be hard to push many towards beta

There have been threads about providing carrots to get people on beta. E.g. a set of unstable features that aren't horribly unstable, just haven't been through all the bikeshadding and baking. Things that people currently abuse RUSTC_BOOTSTRAP for for example.

does the beta channel disappear after the release? or does it point to stable, or to nightly? or do we not release until we have another beta lined up for the beta channel? this will influence the kinds of carrots we can offer in terms of feature previews, especially if we disable the previews on stable.
From my understanding, modulo a few hours while things are being built, stable always points to 1.x, beta to 1.(x + 1) and nightly to 1.(x + 2).
Actually I think that part is wrong. There are a few days prior to the stable release where beta points to the "next" beta but stable hasn't been released yet.
But you can always keep downloading a specific, older beta, right?
I don't know if that's true forever, but I think it is in the short-term.

Wesley Wiser said:

Actually I think that part is wrong. There are a few days prior to the stable release where beta points to the "next" beta but stable hasn't been released yet.

that might have some benefits. users who choose "beta always" could then gain reliable access to feature previews (unless we choose to withdraw a feature after making it available for preview, which hopefully is rare?) and not lose them unpredictably (which they might if we set beta=stable and disabled previews in stable). on the other hand, users who intend to only stay with a beta until the corresponding stable is released might get a nasty surprise by getting a new beta that they didn't expect, prior to that stable release
